dt: {bc}to renounce a throne, high office, dignity, or function
{bc}to relinquish (something, such as sovereign power) formally

pt: {sc}abdicate{/sc} {sc}renounce{/sc} {sc}resign{/sc} mean to give up a position with no possibility of resuming it. {sc}abdicate{/sc} implies a giving up of sovereign power or sometimes an evading of responsibility such as that of a parent.
{sc}renounce{/sc} may replace it but often implies additionally a sacrifice for a greater end.

pt.t: {it}renounced{/it} her inheritance by marrying a commoner

pt: {sc}resign{/sc} applies to the giving up of an unexpired office or trust.

et: borrowed from Latin {it}abdicātus{/it}, past participle of {it}abdicāre{/it}, "to resign, renounce, withdraw," from {it}ab-{/it} {et_link|ab-|ab-} + {it}-dicāre{/it}, ablaut derivative of {it}dīc-{/it} (going back to {it}*deik-{/it}) in {it}dīcere{/it} "to speak, state" {ma}{mat|diction|}{/ma}
shortdef: to renounce a throne, high office, dignity, or function
to relinquish (something, such as sovereign power) formally
